questions.question: Does the application development team understand and actively develop the application?

options.option: Unknown
Little knowledge, no development (example: third-party or commercial off-the-shelf application)
Maintenance mode, no SME knowledge or adequate documentation available
Maintenance mode, SME knowledge is available
Actively developed, SME knowledge is available
Greenfield application

questions.description: How much knowledge does the team have about the application's development or usage?

questions.question: How is the application supported in production?

options.option: Unknown
External support provider with a ticket-driven escalation process; no inhouse support resources
Separate internal support team, separate from the development team, with little interaction between the teams
Multiple teams provide support using an established escalation model
SRE (Site Reliability Engineering) approach with a knowledgeable and experienced operations team
DevOps approach with the same team building the application and supporting it in production

questions.description: Does the team have sufficient knowledge to support the application in production?

questions.question: How much time passes from when code is committed until the application is deployed to production?

options.option: Unknown
Not tracked
More than 6 months
2-6 months
8-30 days
1-7 days
Less than 1 day

questions.description: What is the development latency?

questions.question: How often is the application deployed to production?

options.option: Unknown
Not tracked
Less than once every 6 months
Between once a month and once every 6 months
Weekly
Daily
Several times a day

questions.description: Deployment frequency

questions.question: What is the application's mean time to recover (MTTR) from failure in a production environment?

options.option: Unknown
Not tracked
1 month or more
1-7 days
1-24 hours
Less than 1 hour

questions.description: Average time for the application to recover from failure

questions.question: Does the application have legal and/or licensing requirements?

options.option: Unknown
Multiple legal and licensing requirements
Licensing requirements (examples: per server, per CPU)
Legal requirements (examples: cluster isolation, hardware, PCI or HIPAA compliance)
None

questions.description: Legal and licensing requirements must be assessed to determine their possible impact (cost, fault reporting) on the container platform hosting the application. Examples of legal requirements: isolated clusters, certifications, compliance with the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard or the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. Examples of licensing requirements: per server, per CPU.

questions.question: Which model best describes the application architecture?

options.option: Unknown
Massive monolith (high memory and CPU usage), singleton deployment, vertical scale only
Massive monolith (high memory and CPU usage), non-singleton deployment, complex to scale horizontally
Complex monolith, strict runtime dependency startup order, non-resilient architecture
Resilient monolith (examples: retries, circuit breakers)
Independently deployable components

questions.description: Describe the application architecture in simple terms.

questions.question: Does the application require specific hardware?

options.option: Unknown
Requires CPU that is not supported by Red Hat
Requires custom or legacy hardware (example: USB device)
Requires specific computer hardware (examples: GPUs, RAM, HDDs)
Requires CPU that is supported by Red Hat

questions.description: OpenShift Container Platform runs only on x86, IBM Power, or IBM Z systems

questions.question: What operating system does the application require?

options.option: Unknown
Operating system that is not compatible with OpenShift Container Platform (examples: OS X, AIX, Unix, Solaris)
Linux with custom kernel drivers or a specific kernel version
Linux with custom capabilities (examples: seccomp, root access)
Microsoft Windows
Standard Linux distribution

questions.description: Only Linux and certain Microsoft Windows versions are supported in containers. Check the latest versions and requirements.

questions.question: Does the vendor provide support for a third-party component running in a container?

options.option: Unknown
Not recommended to run the component in a container
No vendor support for containers
Vendor supports containers but with limitations (examples: functionality is restricted, component has not been tested)
Vendor supports their application running in containers but you must build your own images
Vendor fully supports containers, provides certified images
No third-party components required

questions.description: Will the vendor support a component if you run it in a container?

questions.question: Incoming/northbound dependencies

options.option: Unknown
Dependencies are difficult or expensive to change because they are legacy or third-party
Many dependencies exist, can be changed but the process is expensive and time-consuming
Many dependencies exist, can be changed because the systems are internally managed
Internal dependencies only
No incoming/northbound dependencies

questions.description: Systems or applications that call the application

questions.question: Outgoing/southbound dependencies

options.option: Unknown
Dependency availability only verified when application is processing traffic
Dependencies require a complex and strict startup order
Application not ready until dependencies are verified available
Limited processing available if dependencies are unavailable
No outgoing/southbound dependencies

questions.description: Systems or applications that the application calls

questions.question: How resilient is the application? How well does it recover from outages and restarts?

options.option: Unknown
Application cannot be restarted cleanly after failure, requires manual intervention
Application fails when a soutbound dependency is unavailable and does not recover automatically
Application functionality is limited when a dependency is unavailable but recovers when the dependency is available
Application employs resilient architecture patterns (examples: circuit breakers, retry mechanisms)
Application containers are randomly terminated to test resiliency; chaos engineering principles are followed

questions.description: If the application or one of its dependencies fails, how does the application recover from failure? Is manual intervention required?

questions.question: How does the external world communicate with the application?

options.option: Unknown
Non-TCP/IP protocols (examples: serial, IPX, AppleTalk)
TCP/IP, with host name or IP address encapsulated in the payload
TCP/UDP without host addressing (example: SSH)
TCP/UDP encapsulated, using TLS with SNI header
HTTP/HTTPS

questions.description: What protocols do external clients use to communicate with the application?

questions.question: How does the application manage its internal state?

options.option: Unknown
Application components use shared memory within a pod
State is managed externally by another product (examples: Zookeeper or Red Hat Data Grid)
State maintained in non-shared, non-ephemeral storage
Disk shared between application instances
Stateless or ephemeral container storage

questions.description: If the application must manage or retain an internal state, how is this done?

questions.question: How does the application handle service discovery?

options.option: Unknown
Uses technologies that are not compatible with Kubernetes (examples: hardcoded IP addresses, custom cluster manager)
Requires an application or cluster restart to discover new service instances
Uses technologies that are compatible with Kubernetes but require specific libraries or services (examples: HashiCorp Consul, Netflix Eureka)
Uses Kubernetes DNS name resolution
Does not require service discovery

questions.description: How does the application discover services?

questions.question: How is the application clustering managed?

options.option: Unknown
Manually configured clustering (example: static clusters)
Managed by an external off-PaaS cluster manager
Managed by an application runtime that is compatible with Kubernetes
No cluster management required

questions.description: Does the application require clusters? If so, how is clustering managed?

questions.question: How does the application use logging and how are the logs accessed?

options.option: Unknown
Logs are unavailable or are internal with no way to export them
Logs are in a custom binary format, exposed with non-standard protocols
Logs are exposed using syslog
Logs are written to a file system, sometimes as multiple files
Logs are forwarded to an external logging system (example: Splunk)
Logs are configurable (example: can be sent to stdout)

questions.description: How the application logs are accessed

questions.question: Does the application provide metrics?

options.option: Unknown
No metrics available
Metrics collected but not exposed externally
Metrics exposed using binary protocols (examples: SNMP, JMX)
Metrics exposed using a third-party solution (examples: Dynatrace, AppDynamics)
Metrics collected and exposed with built-in Prometheus endpoint support

questions.description: Are application metrics available, if necessary (example: OpenShift Container Platform collects CPU and memory metrics)?

questions.question: How easy is it to determine the application's health and readiness to handle traffic?

options.option: Unknown
No health or readiness query functionality available
Monitored and managed by a custom watchdog process
Basic application health requires semi-complex scripting
Dedicated, independent liveness and readiness endpoints
Health is verified by probes running synthetic transactions

questions.description: How do we determine an application's health (liveness) and readiness to handle traffic?

questions.question: What best describes the application's runtime characteristics?

options.option: Unknown
Deterministic and predictable real-time execution or control requirements
Sensitive to latency (examples: voice applications, high frequency trading applications)
Constant traffic with a broad range of CPU and memory usage
Intermittent traffic with predictable CPU and memory usage
Constant traffic with predictable CPU and memory usage

questions.description: How would the profile of an application appear during runtime (examples: graphs showing CPU and memory usage, traffic patterns, latency)? What are the implications for a serverless application?

questions.question: How long does it take the application to be ready to handle traffic?

options.option: 2-5 minutes
Unknown
More than 5 minutes
1-2 minutes
10-60 seconds
Less than 10 seconds

questions.description: How long the application takes to boot

questions.question: How is the application tested?

options.option: Unknown
No testing or minimal manual testing only
Minimal automated testing, focused on the user interface
Some automated unit and regression testing, basic CI/CD pipeline testing; modern test practices are not followed
Highly repeatable automated testing (examples: unit, integration, smoke tests) before deploying to production; modern test practices are followed
Chaos engineering approach, constant testing in production (example: A/B testing + experimentation)

questions.description: Is the application is tested? Is it easy to test (example: automated testing)? Is it tested in production?

questions.question: How is the application configured?

options.option: Unknown
Configuration files compiled during installation and configured using a user interface
Configuration files are stored externally (example: in a database) and accessed using specific environment keys (examples: host name, IP address)
Multiple configuration files in multiple file system locations
Configuration files built into the application and enabled using system properties at runtime
Configuration retrieved from an external server (examples: Spring Cloud Config Server, HashiCorp Consul)
Configuration loaded from files in a single configurable location; environment variables used

questions.description: How is the application configured? Is the configuration method appropriate for a container? External servers are runtime dependencies.

questions.question: How is the application deployed?

options.option: Unknown
Manual deployment using a user interface
Manual deployment with some automation
Simple automated deployment scripts
Automated deployment with manual intervention or complex promotion through pipeline stages
Automated deployment with a full CI/CD pipeline, minimal intervention for promotion through pipeline stages
Fully automated (GitOps), blue-green, or canary deployment
